Article Title: Why and how Google ‚Äòbreak up order‚Äô is also $20 billion-plus ‚Äòloss‚Äô for Apple
Article Text:

The US Justice Department 's recent antitrust lawsuit against Google has sparked concerns over the potential consequences of its proposed remedies. While Apple does provide users with the option to switch to alternative search engines like Bing or DuckDuckGo, Google remains the pre-selected default in Safari across iPhones, iPads, and Macs.This default setting grants Google access to billions of Apple users, giving it a significant advantage in the search market. The Justice Department's antitrust case centres on the argument that Google's agreement with Apple has helped it create an unfair monopoly in the online search business.During the testimony in the case, Eddy Cue, the senior vice president of services at Apple, told the court that the company went with Google because there was not a better choice at the time. He added that they have ‚Äúalways thought it [Google] was the best‚Äù.Interestingly, reports indicate that Apple explored alternatives to Google, engaging in discussions with Microsoft and DuckDuckGo about potentially using their search engines on Apple devices. Apple even contemplated acquiring Microsoft's Bing search engine but ultimately opted to maintain its partnership with Google.
Article Summary: Google paid $20 billion to Apple in 2022 to be the default search engine on Safari, Apple‚Äôs web browser. In 2021, Google paid Apple around $15 billion. Article Title: Consumer electronics company Arzooo goes for distress sale: What went wrong for the 8-year-old startup
Article Text:
Arzooo cofounders Rishi Raj Rathore (L) and Khushnud Khan (R)

What went wrong with Arzooo

What Moksha Group may do with Arzooo's assets

Mumbai-based Moksha Group has acquired the assets of struggling B2B consumer electronics startup Arzooo. The deal, finalized without disclosing financial details, marks a significant development for both companies. Arzooo, founded by former Flipkart executives Khushnud Khan and Rishi Raj Rathore in 2016, had raised substantial funding but faced challenges including mounting losses and cash flow issues.As part of the acquisition, Moksha Group will gain access to Arzooo's technology platform, intellectual property, and private label brand. According to a report in Economic Times, over the past year, the startup laid off hundreds of employees and its losses mounted. It reportedly blocked payments to its sellers on account of a funding crunch.‚ÄúThe company‚Äôs troubles started after they overspent last year during the Diwali sales, giving heavy discounts and incentives to retailers,‚Äù told a person in the know, who did not wish to be identified to ET. ‚ÄúFollowing this, one of their lenders pulled the credit line, seeing the business was on shaky grounds without additional funding. This led to a capital crunch and the company spiralled into issues, with the only option being to find a buyer,‚Äù the source further added.Moksha Group aims to leverage Arzooo's technology and distribution network to empower small retailers with digital tools, fintech solutions, and affordable financing options. This strategic move is expected to strengthen the position of smaller retailers in the competitive market.The acquisition highlights the challenges faced by many Indian startups, particularly those in the e-commerce sector. As the industry matures, companies must focus on sustainable growth and prudent financial management to avoid similar pitfalls.

Article Title: Zepto is not an ‚ÄúAmazon or Walmart‚Äù but an Indian company with ...: Zepto CEO Aadit Palicha
Article Text:
Why the Big need to become an Indian company

"Zepto is not a rival to Kirana stores"

Success mantra is convenience and efficiency, not pricing

Zepto's monthly cash burn rate is high

Zepto, the fastest-growing quick-commerce startup in the Indian market, has raised an additional $350 million from domestic investors. CEO Aadit Palicha aims to make Zepto a majority Indian-owned company and eventually list it on Indian stock exchanges. In an interview with Economic Times, CEO Palicha said that Zepto is not an ‚ÄúAmazon or Walmart‚Äù but an Indian firm with plans to go public on Indian bourses. Palicha claimed that Zepto‚Äôs latest funding is one of the largest domestic-only rounds for an Indian startup.Founded by Stanford University dropouts Palicha and Kaivalya Vohra, Zepto has emerged as one of the fastest-growing consumer internet firms in India. According to a recent report by Motilal Oswal, Zepto is the second largest player in the sector with a 29% share in the quarter ended June 30, after Blinkit which had a 46% share. The report ‚Äì which did not include Tata Group BigBasket and Flipkart Minutes ‚Äì pegged Swiggy Instamart‚Äôs market share at 24%.The company's focus on domestic ownership is driven by a desire to build trust with policymakers, the public, and shareholders. This move also aligns with the government's increasing scrutiny of foreign-owned quick-commerce firms and their operations in India. After the latest funding, more than 30% of Zepto's stake is with Indian shareholders. These include Manipal group‚Äôs Ranjan Pai, Ramesh and Rajeev Juneja of Mankind Pharma and the Motilal Oswal group. The company‚Äôs overseas investors include General Catalyst, Y Combinator and Nexus Venture Partners.Palicha stressed that Zepto is not a competitor to traditional Kirana stores but rather a complementary service that caters to specific consumer needs, particularly impulse and last-minute purchases. He asserts that the company is a net job creator and contributes to India's growing consumption story."We don‚Äôt accept claims made without real data. The allegations of predatory pricing are not true. Only 0.2% of units sold on our platform in FY24 were below-cost price. 99.8% of units were sold above the cost price given by the manufacturer, with 80% sold at a margin above 20%,‚Äù he said. "If anyone doubts this, we invite them to check our books, which are audited by Ernst & Young."He said that what is happening is a shift in consumer behaviour, where certain categories ‚Äî like impulse or last-minute purchases ‚Äî are coming to quick commerce,‚Äù he said, adding: ‚ÄúBulk and routine purchases remain with Kiranas.‚ÄùTo address concerns about predatory pricing and its impact on Kirana stores, Palicha said that Zepto adheres to fair pricing practices and that the majority of its products are sold at a significant margin. He attributes the shift in consumer behavior, particularly towards quick commerce, to the convenience and efficiency offered by platforms like Zepto.While Zepto has achieved rapid growth, it has also incurred significant costs, including high cash burn rates for dark store expansion and customer acquisition. Palicha acknowledges these costs but expresses confidence in the long-term profitability of the business, citing the increasing profitability of existing dark stores and the decreasing timeline for new stores to break even.

Article Title: Spotify has 'pirated software, cheat codes and adult entertainment' problem
Article Text:
See the posts here

Security issues are spread deep inside

Security researchers have uncovered a concerning trend on Spotify: Playlists and podcasts promoting malware and pirated software. According to a report in 404 Media, people are using Spotify playlist and podcast descriptions to distribute spam, malware, pirated software and cheat codes for video games .One example, highlighted by security researcher Karol Paciorek, involved a playlist titled "Sony Vegas Pro13 Crack Free Download 2024 mysoftwarefree.com." This playlist blatantly advertised a website (mysoftwarefree.com) known to host malicious software.While Spotify reportedly removed the specific playlist in question, Paciorek warns that the problem is widespread. He claimed that users can easily find links to "Vbucks generators" (used to cheat in Fortnite) and "license key cracks" (used to activate pirated software) hidden within playlists and podcast descriptions. "The playlist title in question has been removed," a spokesperson for Spotify told 404 Media in a statement. "Spotify's Platform Rules prohibit posting, sharing, or providing instructions on implementing malware or related malicious practices that seek to harm or gain unauthorized access to computers, networks, systems, or other technologies."The report claims that these listings often exploit Spotify's search engine optimization. Even if Spotify blocks certain keywords within the platform, searching for those keywords on Google still surfaces the malicious links hosted on Spotify.Spammers further manipulate the system by using irrelevant audio content and misleading titles related to popular topics, like TikTok or adult entertainment, to increase search visibility. One example is a podcast named "forlinks" with numerous short episodes that only contain descriptions linking to Turkish gambling sites. Podcast episode titles for such spam accounts often contain popular keywords about TikTok personalities or porn, boosting their search engine reach.
Article Summary: Security researchers have uncovered a concerning trend on Spotify. Playlists and podcasts are promoting malware and pirated software. Spotify reportedly removed the specific playlist in question, but the problem is widespread. The report claims that these listings often exploit Spotify's search engine optimization.

Article Title: Explained: 5 'demands' that are part of the US government's call to break-up Google
Article Text:
What Google said on the DoJ order

Here are some of the demands that the U.S. Justice Department (DOJ) lawyers have made in the case:

Sell Chrome Browser

Sell Android as Last Resort

Five-Year Ban on Browser Ownership

End Exclusive Deals with Apple and Publishers

Mandate Data Sharing and Search Result Licensing

US prosecutors have filed a sweeping antitrust lawsuit against Google, seeking to dismantle the tech giant's dominance in online search. The Department of Justice (DOJ) has proposed a series of drastic measures, including the forced sale of Google's Chrome browser and Android operating system. The DOJ argues that Google has abused its market power to stifle competition and harm consumers. The proposed remedies aim to level the playing field and promote fair competition in the online search market. The outcome of this lawsuit could have far-reaching implications for the tech industry and the broader economy.Responding to DoJ's ruling, Kent Walker, President of Global Affairs, Google & Alphabet, wrote in a blog post, "DOJ had a chance to propose remedies related to the issue in this case: search distribution agreements with Apple, Mozilla, smartphone OEMs, and wireless carriers. Instead, DOJ chose to push a radical interventionist agenda that would harm Americans and America‚Äôs global technology leadership. DOJ‚Äôs wildly overbroad proposal goes miles beyond the Court‚Äôs decision. It would break a range of Google products ‚Äî even beyond Search ‚Äî that people love and find helpful in their everyday lives."US prosecutors have proposed that Google divest its Chrome browser to an approved buyer. The DOJ argues that Google's dominance in both Chrome and Android creates significant barriers for competitors, as they are the primary channels for distributing search engines to users.The DOJ has also suggested that Google could divest its Android operating system if other remedies prove ineffective. This drastic measure underscores the severity of the government's concerns about Google's market power.To further level the playing field, the DOJ proposes a five-year ban on Google owning or investing in a browser, search engine, or related technologies. This would prevent Google from re-establishing its dominance through future acquisitions or investments.The DOJ seeks to end Google's practice of paying billions of dollars annually to Apple to be the default search engine on iPhones and iPads. Additionally, Google would be prohibited from entering into exclusive contracts with publishers that limit competitors' access to valuable content.The most far-reaching proposal requires Google to license its search results to competitors at a nominal cost and share user data with them, subject to privacy constraints. This would allow rivals to better compete with Google's powerful search engine.
Article Summary: US prosecutors have filed a sweeping antitrust lawsuit against Google, seeking to dismantle the tech giant's dominance in online search. The Department of Justice has proposed a series of drastic measures, including the forced sale of Google's Chrome browser and Android operating system. The outcome of this lawsuit could have far-reaching implications for the tech industry and the broader economy.

Article Title: How Blinkit, Swiggy, Zepto and BigBasket are changing grocery shopping in Delhi, Bengaluru, Mumbai and other metros

The surge in quick commerce companies like Swiggy Instamart , Blinkit , Zepto and BigBasket too is playing an important part in this changing consumer behaviour.As Kanaka Bhagwat, head of ecommerce at NielsenIQ, told Economic Times that there has been a significant shift from "top-up" to "stock-up" purchases, driven by the convenience and assortment offered by quick commerce and e-commerce platforms.Ready-to-eat foods have seen exceptional growth on e-commerce channels, with sales soaring 52% year-over-year. Consumers are increasingly opting to purchase monthly essentials, including bulk packs of staples, on these platforms for convenience.E-commerce dominates metros, Kiranas still strong beyond metro citiesIn the September 2024 quarter, quick commerce and e-commerce contributed 85% to incremental sales in metro markets, a stark contrast to the previous year when offline channels dominated. This shift underscores the growing importance of e-commerce in urban areas.While traditional trade (Kirana stores) still accounts for 85% of FMCG sales nationally, the rapid rise of quick commerce is impacting urban markets. Companies like Dabur and Nestle are adjusting their inventory strategies in traditional trade channels to adapt to this shift.In the last few months, quick-commerce platforms have expanded their offerings beyond FMCG to include apparel, durables, smartphones, footwear, and jewelry. The reason that these involve planned purchases and larger ticket sizes, buying say a kurta or TV is not same as ordering groceries.Redseer Strategy Consultants forecasts significant growth for India's quick-commerce market, projecting it to reach $6 billion by March 2025, driven by increased user adoption and higher spending per transaction.

Article Title: The 'Rs 300 crore unsold inventory charge' that Mamaearth has 'trashed'

Article Title: Why Google reportedly told employees to 'CC' company's legal team in all important internal communication
Article Text:
What the memo urged employees to do

How Google‚Äôs communication practice came to fore

Google, in a confidential memo to employees in 2008, outlined its long-standing efforts to minimise and control its internal communications, a report has said. The memo also urged the employees to add a Google lawyer to the list of recipients ‚Äì a practice aimed at shielding the tech giant from potential legal challenges.A report by The New York Times highlighted that this ‚Äòculture of deletion‚Äô within the company has come to light through recent antitrust lawsuits. This practice reportedly started from 2008, when Google faced antitrust scrutiny over an advertising deal with its rival Yahoo, the report cited a memo as saying.Facing antitrust scrutiny and various legal battles, Google executives urged employees to exercise caution in their internal communications, warning that casual remarks could be used against the company in court. They encouraged employees to avoid speculation, sarcasm, and discussions on sensitive topics, the report added.‚ÄúWe believe that information is good,‚Äù the executives told employees in the memo, adding that employees should refrain from speculation and sarcasm as well as ‚Äúthink twice‚Äù before writing one another to minimise the odds that a lawsuit may flush out comments that may be incriminating.‚ÄúDon‚Äôt comment before you have all the facts,‚Äù the employees were told, as per the New York Times report. The company also encouraged employees to mark documents as ‚Äúattorney-client privileged‚Äù and include lawyers as recipients, even in non-legal discussions.To further limit potential legal exposure, Google reportedly implemented technological measures, including making its instant messaging tool ‚Äúoff the record‚Äù and automatically deleting chat histories. This practice of minimising internal records has continued for over 15 years, the report highlighted.The company exempted instant messaging from automatic legal holds, requiring employees to manually preserve their chat history if involved in litigation. This practice effectively minimised the availability of such communications in legal proceedings, the report said.Evidence from recent antitrust trials against Google, brought by Epic Games and the Department of Justice (DoJ), has shed light on Google's efforts to suppress internal communications. In fact, during its trials, Google faced criticism for its actions as all the judges in all three antitrust cases pulled up the company for its communications practices.While Judge James Donato who presided over the case brought by Epic Games Epic said there was ‚Äúan ingrained systemic culture of suppression of relevant evidence within Google‚Äù and that the company‚Äôs behaviour was ‚Äúa frontal assault on the fair administration of justice.‚ÄùSimailry, Judge Leonie Brinkema, who is overseeing Google‚Äôs antitrust case involving advertising technology, said in August that the company‚Äôs document retention policies were ‚Äúnot the way in which a responsible corporate entity should function.‚Äù‚ÄúAn awful lot of evidence has likely been destroyed,‚Äù she added.Google responded by saying that it had provided ‚Äúmillions of documents‚Äù in the Justice Department cases alone.Google said in a statement that it took ‚Äúseriously our obligations to preserve and produce relevant documents. We have for years responded to inquiries and litigation, and we educate our employees about legal privilege.‚Äù
Article Summary: Google executives urged employees to exercise caution in their internal communications, warning that casual remarks could be used against the company in court. The memo also urged the employees to add a Google lawyer to the list of recipients ‚Äì a practice aimed at shielding the tech giant from potential legal challenges. This practice reportedly started from 2008 when Google faced antitrust scrutiny over an advertising deal with its rival Yahoo.

Article Title: Retired lecturer loses Rs 45 lakh to 'Digital arrest' scam: WhatsApp call; fake Supreme Court receipts; Google Pay, Paytm payments and more
Article Text:
Here‚Äôs what happened

A retired lecturer in Hyderabad fell victim to a "digital arrest" scam, losing Rs 45 lakh. Posing as a CBI officer, the scammer claimed Sharma's Aadhaar card was linked to illegal activities. Through video calls and threats of arrest, the fraudster manipulated Sharma into transferring funds to various accounts, using fake receipts to maintain the facade.The victim, 73-year-old Ch Purshotham Sharma received a call from someone who claimed to have intercepted a parcel containing banned drugs linked to Sharma's Aadhaar card number, implicating him in a money laundering case. To prevent his alleged "arrest," the caller provided Sharma with a contact number for a purported CBI officer in Ahmedabad and instructed him to cooperate with the investigation.The scammer then conducted a video call with Sharma while dressed in a police uniform. The scammer then pressured Sharma into sharing his bank account details and tricked him into making multiple payments through Google Pay, Paytm, net banking, and RTGS (Real-Time Gross Settlement) to various accounts. The transactions, made over multiple days, totalled Rs 45.5 lakh.To further convince Sharma, the fraudsters even sent him fake receipts, supposedly from the Supreme Court and signed by the registrar, as confirmation of his payments.Sharma eventually realised he had been deceived and approached the Rachakonda Cyber Crime Police to file a complaint. A case was registered under relevant sections of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) and the Information Technology Act, including charges of identity theft and cheating by personation.This incident highlights the increasing sophistication of cyber scams targeting unsuspecting individuals. 'Digital arrest' scams, where fraudsters impersonate law enforcement officials and exploit the fear of legal repercussions, are becoming a significant threat.
Article Summary: A retired lecturer in Hyderabad fell victim to a "digital arrest" scam. Posing as a CBI officer, the scammer claimed Sharma's card was linked to illegal activities. Through video calls and threats of arrest, the fraudster manipulated Sharma into transferring funds to various accounts.
